elements.name: MedicalPanel
elements.description:
Under BC Law, a child under the age of 19 may consent to their own health care – if they understand the details of the treatment including the risks and benefits and the health treatment has been determined to be in their best interests. For more information on the Infants Act, visit BC Laws.

When a minor does not have the capacity to consent, the consent of the child’s guardian is required. Normally, the guardian will instruct the medical, dental or other health care provider and give or refuse consent on behalf of the child.

Subject to s. 17 of the Infants Act, the parental responsibility of giving, refusing or withdrawing consent to medical, dental or other health-related treatments for the child may be allocated to one or more of the child’s guardians under an agreement or court order.

elements.name: yesExistingParentingArrangementsInfo
elements.title: If parenting arrangements have already been formalized in a written agreement or court order, the Family Law Act sets out specific processes about relocation.</br></br>Under <a href='https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/11025_04#division_d2e5455' target='blank'>s. 66 of the Family Law Act<a>, if a guardian plans to relocate, with or without the child, and the relocation can reasonably be expected to have a significant impact on the child’s relationship with a guardian, the child’s guardian who plans to relocate themselves or a child, or both, must give all other guardians at least 60 days’ written notice of the date of relocation and proposed location.</br></br>The other guardian can apply for an order to prohibit the relocation. You can apply for an order to prohibit the relocation by selecting relocation of a child on the first step in this service. Remember to de-select priority parenting matter.

elements.name: PreventRemovalPanel
elements.description:
Section 64 of the Family Law Act provides for two types of orders about the removal of a child. The first type allows the court to order that a person not remove a child from a certain area. For example, an order might say that neither parent may take the child out of the Lower Mainland without the other parent’s consent. This type of order is usually about parenting together and making sure each guardian knows where the child is.

The second type is used where there is concern that a person may remove a child from BC and not return that child. In this situation, the court may order the person who may leave with the child to surrender their passport or give security (usually a specific amount of money) to the court to prevent them from leaving.

elements.name: wrongfulReturn
elements.title: Do you believe that a child has been wrongfully removed to or retained in a member country under the `1980 Hague Convention`, either to BC or from BC?
elements.description:
Section 80 of the Family Law Act provides that the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has the force of law in B.C. The Hague Convention is an international treaty in force among some 90 countries. Its goal is to help with the court process to return a child wrongfully removed or retained from their place of habitual residence.

The Convention applies to children under the age of 16. In most Convention cases, children are abducted by one of their parents.

elements.name: hagueConventionMatterFAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: Where can I get help with a Hague Convention matter?
elements.body:
BC has a central authority that assists parents whose children have been abducted across international borders, either to or from BC, and parents who are seeking contact or access to children in another country. The central authority provides information and support to parents directly, or assists their legal counsel in BC or in the other country.

For more information about BC’s central authority, click here.

BC’s central authority can be contacted by email at BCCentralAuthority@gov.bc.ca or by telephone at the contact numbers provided on the BC Government website.

Lawyers: To find a lawyer or to have a free consultation with a lawyer for up to 30 minutes, contact the Lawyer Referral Service at 1-800-663-1919

elements.name: ChildServicesPanel
elements.description:
Sometimes a Family Law Act order about parenting arrangements (including parenting time or parental responsibilities) or guardianship of a child can allow a child to be returned or prevent the removal of a child under the Child, Family and Community Service Act.

If a director under the Child, Family and Community Service Act is involved with the child, you may be eligible for help from the Parents Legal Centre (PLC). Call PLC at 1-888-522-2752 to find out if you qualify for a free lawyer and an advocate. If you already have a lawyer working with you on your child protection issue, Parents Legal Centres can't help you.

For more information about Parents Legal Centres visit their website at https://family.legalaid.bc.ca/visit/parents-legal-centre.

elements.name: confirmChildServicesPathway
elements.title: I am applying for:
elements.description: If you are not a guardian of the child and you need an order about parenting arrangements, you must also apply for guardianship of the child.</br>Select all that apply.

choices.text:
Parenting Arrangements
Parenting arrangements are how each guardian will parent their child, including each guardian’s `parental responsibilities` for decision making about a child and the `parenting time` each guardian spends with a child. Parental responsibilities may be shared or exercised separately. The only thing you can consider in making your parenting arrangements is what is in the best interests of the child.

Guardianship of a child
Guardianship is who is responsible for a child. Only guardians have parental responsibilities and parenting time with a child. An agreement or order about parenting arrangements can say a child’s guardians share parental responsibilities or parenting time. Or it can say one guardian is responsible for more of the parenting decisions and has more of the parenting time with the child.
Anyone who wants to become a guardian can apply, including a parent who is not a guardian or anyone else (even if they are not related to the child). If you are applying under section 51 of the Family Law Act to become a guardian of a child who has been removed or is at risk of removal by the Director under section 30, section 36 or section 42 of the Child, Family and Community Service Act you can apply as a priority parenting matter but you must still meet the requirements under section 51 of the Family Law Act.
